title: Ticket #2366: Remove version from OpSys and add OpSysVer and Distro attributes
description:
We should gather some of the accumulated wisdom from the Batlab and do a better job of identifying the operating system, distro and version in execute nodes.

OPSYS on Windows machines should be WINDOWS

See OPSYS_NAME comment below.

Most Windows programs don't care what version of the Windows OS they run on. But Condor sets the OPSYS attribute for Windows execute nodes to a value that contains the version number (WINNT50, WINNT51, etc). So it requires effort on the part of the user to specify that their program will run on most versions of windows. The default behavior for Condor is that programs will execute only on the nodes that have the same version of Windows as the submit node.

The {Quote: OpSys} attribute should just be WINDOWS by default. And there should be a parameter ENABLE_VERSIONED_OPSYS that enables the old behavior of appending the OS version number to the OPSYS attribute. This will default to false

A new attribute OpSysVer will contain an integer value representing the version number of the OS. Win2k = 500, WinXP = 501, Win2003 = 502, Vista = 600, Server2008 = 600 or 601, Win7 = 601.

A new attibute OpSysAndVer will have the legacy OpSys value, where WinXP = "WINNT51", etc.

changes for unixen

Most of the commercial Unix flavors also have OS version appended to OpSys. But support for non Linux flavors of unix is mostly legacy, so we will not change the way these machines publish OpSys. OpSysVer and OpSysAndVer will be added to these machines, but ENABLE_VERSIONED_OPSYS will default to true so OpSys and OpSysAndVer will be the same.

changes for Linux

For linux variants, {Quote: OpSys} carries no meaning, we need to publish additional attributes: DISTRO and DISTROVER with values to be set using techniques from the batlab's hawkeye scripts. 

  OpSys
    "WINDOWS"
    "RedHat"
    "FreeBSD"

  OpSysVer (Major * 100 + Minor)

  OpSysMajorVer
    5

  OpSysAndVer
    "WINNT51"
    "REDHAT5"
    "SOLARIS23"

  OpSysName
    "Windows XP"
    "Red Hat 5.11"
    "Ubuntu 10.04"
    "Suse 10.2"
remarks:
see also #1692

2011-Sep-09 12:17:20 by nleroy:
The published attributes should include:

  • OPSYS (as described above; see comments below for OPSYS_NAME)

  • OPSYS_NAME (Alternative, keep OPSYS as previous for backward compatibility, but OPSYS_NAME would be more general):
    • Linux
    • Windows
    • FreeBSD
    • Thoughts on this one?

  • OPSYSVER (as described above)

  • OPSYSANDVER (as described above)

  • DISTRO_NAME: Operating system distribution name
    • "openSUSE" for openSUSE 11.4
    • "Redhat" for Redhat 5.7
    • "Ubuntu" for Ubuntu 10.04.03

  • DISTRO: Operating system distribution and version
    • "opensuse_11.4" for openSUSE 11.4
    • "RHAP5" for Redhat 5.7
    • "ubuntu_10.04.03" for Ubuntu 10.04.03

  • DISTRO_VERSION: Version of the operating system distribution
    • "11.4" for openSUSE 11.4
    • "5.7" for Redhat 5.7
    • "10.04.03" for Ubuntu 10.04.03

  • DISTRO_MAJOR: Major version of the operating system distribution. Should this be an integer instead of a string?
    • "11" for openSUSE 11.4
    • "7" for Redhat 5.7
    • "10" for Ubuntu 10.04.03

  • DISTRO_MINOR: Minor version of the operating system distribution. Should this be an integer instead of a string?
    • "4" for openSUSE 11.4
    • "7" for Redhat 5.7
    • "04" for Ubuntu 10.04.03

  • DISTRO_RELEASE: Release version of the operating system distribution. Should this be an integer instead of a string?
    • "0" for openSUSE 11.4
    • "0" for Redhat 5.7
    • "03" for Ubuntu 10.04.03

2011-Sep-09 12:54:18 by johnkn:
I disagree with the proposed change to use OPSYS_NAME instead of re-defining OPSYS. And as a consequence, I also disagree with having DISTRO be a string containing the distro name and version. This is exactly the kind of over-specificity that we are trying to get away from.

Also, version numbers should be integers, not strings so that we can do greater than and lessthan comparisons.

how about DISTRO_DISPLAY_NAME or DISTRO_LABEL to be the string value that contains the fully qualified distro name and version?

so

  • DISTRO
    • "openSUSE" for openSUSE 11.4
    • "RedHat" for Redhat 5.7

  • DISTROVER
    • 1104 for openSUSE 11.4
    • 507 for Redhat 5.7

  • DISTRO_DISPLAY_NAME
    • "openSUSE 11.4" for openSUSE 11.4
    • "Redhat 5.7" for Redhat 5.7

I should also note that Windows currently has the following attributes defined for version info. We should conform to the same naming convention. 

WindowsMajorVersion = 6
WindowsMinorVersion = 1
WindowsServicePackMajorVersion = 0
WindowsServicePackMinorVersion = 0

2011-Sep-13 14:22:31 by adesmet:
Encoding version numbers as integers (for comparison purposes) is non-intuitive and fragile in the face of some distribution deciding to make, for example, the minor portion "123". #2395 proposes having new ClassAd functions that know how to compare version numbers as strings directly, allowing people to say more clearly what they mean. e.g. 

# Require RHES 5.4 through 6.999
REQUIREMENTS=DISTRO=="RedHatEnterpriseServer" && versionOkay(DISTRO_VER, "5.4", "6.*")

2011-Sep-13 14:29:41 by adesmet:
Lans Carstensen suggests advertising/using information from lsb_release. This should be a reasonably portable way of learning at run time the distro and version on Linux, as well as some of the capabilities promised by the LSB. 

# Capabilities list, colon seperated
#   :core-3.0-amd64:core-3.0-ia32:core-3.0-noarch:graphics-3.0-amd64:graphics-3.0-ia32:graphics-3.0-noarch
LSB_VERSION=`/usr/bin/lsb_release -v -s`

# Distribution name (Ubuntu, ScientificCERNSLC, RedHatEnterpriseServer)
LSB_ID=`/usr/bin/lsb_release -i -s`

# Distribution version (10.04, 4.8, 5.6)
LSB_RELEASE=`/usr/bin/lsb_release -r -s`

2011-Sep-14 10:26:14 by dthain:
I would like to add some thoughts about the user experience that might be used to guide the technical discussion.

Most users (that I work with) are not knowledgable about the distinctions between different kinds of Linux. The local sysadmins worry about installing and managing the machines, and the users often don't even know what distro is in use. They see a machine listed as LINUX in condor_status and assume a program compiled on one Linux machine will run on another Linux machine. They are astonished and disappointed to find this is not the case. This happens a lot at universities where multiple IT operations are contributing to the same Condor pool.

Thus, I think that the default system configuration should be very conservative about choosing execution machines that are likely to be compatible with the submitting machine. This gives the highest probability of success for the beginning user, but still allows the expert user to choose whatever resources they like. In the case of Linux, jobs should only run on machines with the same distribution and the same version, to some number of significant digits.

Further, the system should make some effort to show the user that machines are significantly different, through condor_status and other displays, so that they understand why things don't match.

There are multiple ways to accomplish this.

Approach A - The prevailing Condor philosophy seems to be to define as many properties as possible, and let the knowledgable user pick from them. (OpSys, Distro, MajorVersion, MinorVersion, etc...) However, this has two downsides. (1) The default SUBMIT_EXPRS become rather complicated and difficult to override. For example, if the user defines Distro in their Requirements expression, should that cause MajorVersion to be dropped from the default SUBMIT_EXPRS? (2) A lot more information needs to be presented in condor_status and frieds to make it clear to users what is going on.

Approach B - The opposite approach would be to put define OpSys to be something very specific like "REDHAT" or even "REDHAT5". This has the advantage of requiring no change to the existing default submit expressions logic, and also makes it abundantly clear to the user that one Linux distribution is incompatible with the other. They will have to go out of their way to try to run a code on multiple operating systems.

Note that approach B does not prevent the use of additional machine attributes for the expert user, but it is simply emphasizing the use of OpSys as the common case.

I favor the latter approach, but whatever approach is taken, I think it is important that the default submit expression be much more conservative than just selecting OpSys=="LINUX".
